questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of alcohol abuse, altered sensorium, and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended with palpable hepatomegaly and splenomegaly and sclerae are icteric. The other examination findings are given below. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Pathophysiology

Alcohol Metabolism
  • Ethanol is primarily metabolized in the liver by enzymes, particularly alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1).
  • This metabolism produces acetaldehyde, a toxic intermediate, which can cause cellular damage.

Oxidative Stress
  • The metabolism of alcohol generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increases oxidative stress within liver cells.
  • This oxidative damage leads to lipid peroxidation, protein modifications, and DNA damage, contributing to hepatocyte injury and inflammation.

Inflammatory Response
  • Alcohol consumption stimulates the activation of immune cells (e.g., Kupffer cells) leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6).
  • These cytokines promote inflammation and can further damage hepatocytes.

Altered Lipid Metabolism
  • Alcohol disrupts normal lipid metabolism, leading to fat accumulation in liver cells (steatosis).
  • This accumulation can progress to steatohepatitis, where inflammation and liver cell injury occur.

Fibrosis and Cirrhosis
  • Chronic inflammation and injury stimulate the activation of hepatic stellate cells, which produce collagen and lead to fibrosis.
  • Over time, repeated injury can result in cirrhosis, characterized by scarring and loss of normal liver architecture.

General
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Fever, malaise, jaundice, history of alcohol intake + (at least within last 8 weeks before symptom onset)

Abdominal
  • Right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites
  • Caput medusae: enlarged veins radiating from the umbilicus
  • Bleeding varices (portal hypertension)

Dermatological
  • Spider angioma, palmar erythema, ecchymosis

Reproductive
  • Gynaecomastia, gonadal atrophy, loss of libido, amenorrhea

Neurological
  • Peripheral neuropathy: tingling and numbness usually over feet
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: Ophthalmoplegia, confusion, ataxia + anterograde amnesia
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: Asterixis (most prominent finding), altered sensorium, sleep disturbances, lethargy

Others
  • Dupuytren’s contracture, temporal muscle wasting, parotid gland enlargement

AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)

Non-specific ; ↑ (<300-400)

ALT (Alanine aminotransferase)

Specific for liver injury ; ↑ (<300-400)

AST/ALT ratio: ≥ 2: 1

Specific for ALD

ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)

Elevated in bile duct pathologies

GGT (γ-glutamyl transferase)

Non-specific marker of ALD

5’-Nucleotidase

Specific marker for bile duct pathologies

S.Bilirubin

Usually normal/mildly ↑

S.Albumin

↓ in chronic liver disease (cirrhosis)

Carbohydrate-deficient transferrin (CDT)

Best serum marker for alcoholic liver disease.

What is the child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dl, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR =2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites?
questions.explanation:

Poorly controlled

< 2

> 3

> 3.5

3 - 3.5

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presented with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal oedema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose Norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: Which of the following conditions leads to the development of wing beating tremor?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Wilson's Disease

Hepatic Symptoms
  • Chronic Hepatitis: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes due to copper accumulation in the liver.
  • Cirrhosis: Portal hypertension, variceal bleeding as a result of long-term copper accumulation and fibrosis.
  • Acute Liver Failure: Coagulopathy, jaundice, encephalopathy.

Neurological Symptoms
  • Movement Disorders: Tremors (flapping or wind-beating tremor), dystonia, ataxia, dysarthria due to copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Parkinsonism-like symptoms : Rigidity, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity from copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric: Depression, personality changes, cognitive decline.

Ocular Features
  • Kayser-Fleischer Rings: Brown/greenish rings in the cornea due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane.

 

  • Sunflower Cataract: Rare, (copper deposition in the lens).

Renal Features
  • Renal Tubular Acidosis (Fanconi Syndrome): Due to copper accumulation in renal tubules.

Hematologic Features
  • Hemolytic Anemia: Copper-induced red cell damage.

Skeletal Features
  • Osteopenia, osteoporosis, joint arthropathy

questions.text: Which benzodiazepine is suitable for the safe administration to a 40-year-old chronic alcoholic experiencing withdrawal symptoms, based on the liver function tests that indicated AST levels of 140 IU/L, ALT levels of 110 IU/L, and GGT levels of 500 IU/L?

A 20-year-old male presented with a history of yellowing of the skin and eyes for 11 weeks, but he does not have any other symptoms. He had a viral infection 10 days ago and experienced a similar episode of yellowing 2 years ago for 2 weeks. Upon further questioning, he mentioned having long hours of basketball practice 2 years ago, which left him physically exhausted. His current blood tests show a serum bilirubin level of 2.4 mg/dL, with unconjugated bilirubin at 2.1 mg/dL and conjugated bilirubin at 0.3 mg/dL. His liver enzyme levels (AST and ALT) are normal. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Gilbert Syndrome

About
  • Gilber Gilbert Syndrome (GS) is a common, benign condition with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and normal liver function tests, affecting up to 8% of people, more common in males.

Pathophysiology
  • Caused by reduced UGT1A1 enzyme activity (10–35% of normal), often due to a TA insertion variant in the UGT1A1 promoter (A[TA]7TAA).
  • Inheritance is typically autosomal recessive with the promoter variant; some cases show dominant inheritance with other mutations.

Clinical Features

 
  • Serum bilirubin <51 μmol/L (<3 mg/dL), fluctuating with stress, fasting, alcohol, or illness; jaundice may occur during elevations.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, though jaundice can occur during episodes of elevated bilirubin levels.
  • Often diagnosed incidentally in adolescence or adulthood.

Investigations
  • Serum bilirubin levels are intermittently high, with Normal liver function tests and hepatic histology.
  • UGT1A1 gene testing may reveal the A[TA]7TAA promoter variant.

Management
  • Lifestyle adjustments, such as avoiding alcohol and maintaining regular calorie intake, may help manage bilirubin levels.
  • Phenobarbital can normalize bilirubin levels if required.
  • Caution with drugs metabolized by UGT1A1 (e.g., irinotecan, HIV protease inhibitors) due to risk of toxicity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 100,000, and SGPT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Tenofovir for >40 week

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant discomfort and grade Il steatohepatitis of the liver. He has a history of regular intake of 2-3 alcoholic drinks daily and has a BMI of 29. What will be the most appropriate advice to the patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Lifestyle modification + vitamin E + Ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.explanation:
Steatosis

Only lifestyle modifications:

  • Alcohol abstinence
  • Dietary changes
  • Exercise

Steato-Hepatitis

  • Oral Prednisolone 32 mg/day for 4 weeks
  • Check S.Bilirubin levels 1 week after starting steroids
  • Other drugs: N-acetyl cysteine, Pentoxifylline, anti-TNFα agents

Cirrhosis (Organ failure/ Portal hypertension)
  • Liver transplant

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing a 55-year-old male with chronic alcoholism, who presented to the emergency department with unconsciousness and hypotension, the last intake of alcohol being 7 days ago, showing liver with coarse echotexture and mild portal vein dilatation on ultrasound?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage.

options.label: B
options.text: Perform emergency endoscopy to assess for varices.

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate treatment with thiamine and chlordiazepoxide.

options.label: D
options.text: Conduct a CT scan of the brain.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Administer lactulose and wait for stool passag

questions.text: A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and clay-colored stools. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to cigarette smoking. On examination icterus was present. Liver function test results are given below: Total Bilirubin - 18.5 Direct Bilirubin — 7.5 SGOT - 723 SGPT-812 Which investigations would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis?

options.label: C
options.text: HBsAg, lgM antiHBc, AntiHDV, AntiHCV, Anti HEV

questions.correct_answer: B. AntiHAV, HBsAg, lgM antiHBc, AntiHCV
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - AntiHAV, HBsAg, lgM antiHBc, AntiHCV

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific marker for alcoholism?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - GGT

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of child pugh classification?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - SGOT

questions.text: What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of a 6-year-old patient who has been experiencing fever for the past 3 days and complains of pain in the right upper abdomen , and upon examination, tenderness is observed in the right upper quadrant ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - USG (Ultrasonography)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a post-hepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Budd Ch

Pre-Hepatic

Hepatic

Post-Hepatic
  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Splenic vein thrombosis
  • Banti syndrome (massive splenomegaly)
    • Idiopathic and more common in Japan
  • Pre-sinusoidal
    • Schistosomiasis
  • Sinusoidal
    • Cirrhosis
  • Post sinusoidal
    • Veno occlusive disease
    • Radiation, Herbal tea
  • Budd Chiari Syndrome
  • Inferior vena cava webs
  • Restrictive cardio myopathy
  • Constrictive pericarditis (compliance will reduced)

questions.text: Which antiretroviral drug is not utilized in cases of concurrent HIV and hepatitis B infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Abacav

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below . Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child’s diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Serum ceruloplasmin lev

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Hepatitis C:
